awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  SHINE:  Study of Long-Term Variability of Solar Chromospheric Activity in Multiple Solar Cycles
awd_abstract_narration:
This 3-year SHINE project is aimed at building a multi-decadal database of H-alpha images using various sources and studying the long-term variation in the database to understand the cyclic behavior of the solar activity.  The three project teams will study the statistical properties of filaments, track differential rotation and meridional flows, and investigate the chirality-hemispheric helicity relation, which is essential for understanding the long-term variation of magnetic fields, interior flows and helicity.  The project has a strong education component since all three PI institutions have very active programs in education and outreach; the NJIT and CSUN have highly diverse environment, with many minority students.  This SHINE project is multidisciplinary in nature since it requires expertise in computer science, engineering, statistics, and physics. The project will promote strong international collaborations for the benefit of advancing space weather research both in the USA and worldwide.
  
The research plan of this 3-year SHINE project includes three main tasks.  The first task is to study the long-term variation of the statistical properties of filaments that carries important information about the magnetic signature of the solar cycles.   The project team will focus the research on the statistical and cycle dependent properties of filaments, in particular polar crown filaments that are related to the interface between the new and the old solar cycles.  The second main task is to track plasma flows using features from H-alpha images as proxy for the magnetic features.  The most important components include the differential rotation and meridional flows.  Both are closely related to the dynamo signature of solar cycles.  Since the SOHO and SDO data are limited to solar cycles 23 and 24, which may be atypical in respect to low level of activity, to accomplish this task the project team will utilize their own data, which spans over 9 solar cycles of both high and low amplitudes.  The third task is to investigate the distribution of filament chirality and their cycle variations, which reflect the global structure of helicity.  The project is directly relevant to the NSF's SHINE program, because it will provide important knowledge about the long-term variation of the global solar activity, which is the major source of high-energy disturbances in the solar, heliospheric, and interplanetary environment.  Such knowledge is critical for accurate modeling and prediction of space weather conditions from the solar surface to the Earth and beyond.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

Understanding the Sun's Dynamics: Insights from Chromospheric Observations

Introduction: In the pursuit of unraveling the mysteries of our dynamic sun, we undertook an extensive study utilizing data from the Kodaikenal Observatory and San Fernando Observatory. The primary focus of this research has been on understanding the mechanisms underlying filament eruptions, which are responsible for solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs). Over the period of 2010 to 2014, the team examined an impressive 1014 filament eruption events using data from the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO), aiming to discern their correlation with CMEs.

Key Findings: The findings from this comprehensive study shed light on the diverse nature of filament eruption events. A notable discovery is that 50% of these events were associated with both two-ribbon flares and CMEs. Intriguingly, 26% of the events occurred without any flare or CME, emphasizing the variety in the eruptive behavior of solar filaments. Furthermore, 7% of the events lacked both flare and CME, while 12% exhibited flares without accompanying CMEs. These results provide crucial insights into the dichotomy between confined and eruptive filament ejections, enriching our understanding of solar dynamics. While this work confirmed our earlier findings with a very limited data set, that 50% of the filament eruption events with two ribbon flares are associated with CME, we found two catagories of events that had minor CMEs without any flare.

Implications for Space Weather: Understanding the relationship between filament eruptions, flares, and CMEs is essential for predicting and mitigating the impact of space weather on Earth. The observed diversity in the outcomes of filament eruptions highlights the complexity of solar phenomena and emphasizes the need for refined models to forecast space weather events accurately. Such insights can contribute to enhancing the reliability of space-based technologies and safeguarding critical infrastructure on Earth.

Upcoming Research Publication: Our research team is currently in the process of documenting and presenting their findings in a comprehensive paper. The upcoming publication will provide a detailed account of the methodologies employed, data analysis techniques, and the significance of the observed associations between filament eruptions and solar flares/CMEs. The scientific community eagerly anticipates this contribution, which will enrich existing knowledge and foster further exploration in solar physics.

Variability of Total Solar Irradiance: Beyond filament eruptions, our research extends to the variability of total solar irradiance (TSI), a crucial parameter influencing Earth's climate. TSI is known to primarily vary on an 11-year time scale, influenced by features such as sunspots, plage, and faculae. However, the team delves into the finer details, investigating periodic variations at solar-surface-rotation time scales.

Insights from Ground- and Space-Based Data: Utilizing data from the San Fernando Observatory and the Total Irradiance Monitor (TIM) onboard the Solar Radiation and Climate Experiment (SORCE) spacecraft, the researchers examined daily ground- and space-based data spanning from early 2003 to late 2018. To overcome missing pixels in the datasets, an innovative autoregressive gap-filling method was employed, enabling the construction of continuous time series for analysis.

Periodic Variations: The Fourier and wavelet spectral techniques, along with Lomb–Scargle periodograms, revealed statistically significant periodicities in the range of 25 to 35 days. Remarkably, all time series exhibited maximum power at 27 days, with secondary periods at 29–30 days and 34–35 days. This consistent periodicity across different datasets underscores the robustness of the findings.

Solar Cycle Influence: During the active part of the solar cycle, wavelet analyses demonstrated a common high power at surface-solar-rotation scales for both the red-continuum photometric sum and TSI. The phase relation at these scales, however, remains indefinite. Notably, during the solar minimum between Solar Cycles 23 and 24, variations in TSI were correlated with variations in the photometric index ΣK, derived from Ca II K-line photometric sums, and the magnetic flux in the solar activity latitudinal band. This suggests that TSI changes during the minimum are influenced by the reduced line-blanketing effect of diffused magnetic fields.

Conclusion: In summary, this research not only advances our understanding of filament eruptions and their diverse outcomes but also provides valuable insights into the variability of total solar irradiance. The forthcoming publication promises to contribute significantly to solar physics, guiding future research and enhancing our ability to predict and comprehend solar activity's impact on Earth. As we continue to unravel the intricacies of our dynamic sun, these findings mark a significant step forward in our journey to comprehend the celestial phenomena that shape our solar system.
